definition: An object or other creation (e.g. narrative work) from which all later copies and variations are derived
A series of sounds organized in time, employing melody, harmony, tempo etc. usually to convey a mood.
A thin layer of some substance; a pellicle; a membranous covering, causing opacity.
A judgment, sentence, or final decision. Specifically: The decision of arbitrators in a case submitted.
A book specially designed to keep photographs, stamps, or autographs.

The conscious production or arrangement of sounds, colours, forms, movements, or other elements in a manner that affects the senses and emotions, usually specifically the production of the beautiful in a graphic or plastic medium.
A building or institution dedicated to the acquisition, conservation, study, exhibition, and educational interpretation of objects having scientific, historical, cultural or artistic value.
A specification of an object or process, referring to requirements to be satisfied and thus conditions to be met for them to solve a problem.
One's structure or make-up: form, shape, bodily proportions.
A person who creates art.
A set of items or amount of material procured or gathered together.
A place for storing earlier, and often historical, material. An archive usually contains documents (letters, records, newspapers, etc.) or other types of media kept for historical interest.
A representation of anything (as a person, a landscape, a building) upon canvas, paper, or other surface, by drawing, painting, printing, photography, etc.
To infuse into the mind; to communicate to the spirit; to convey, as by a divine or supernatural influence; to disclose preternaturally; to produce in, as by inspiration.
To apply paint to.
A set of items or amount of material procured or gathered together.
A meeting or gathering.
A painting or other picture of a person, especially the head and shoulders.
To move or develop something.
An artist who paints pictures.
A person who sings, often professionally.
The act or process of compiling or gathering together from various sources.
The art and technology of producing images on photosensitive surfaces, and its digital counterpart.
To apply paint to.
Having or revealing creative skill.
A building or institution dedicated to the acquisition, conservation, study, exhibition, and educational interpretation of objects having scientific, historical, cultural or artistic value.
A specification of an object or process, referring to requirements to be satisfied and thus conditions to be met for them to solve a problem.
An illustration or artwork done with the use of paint.
The act of innovating; the introduction of something new, in customs, rites, etc.
To appear as a featured performer or headliner, especially in an entertainment program.
A three dimensional work of art created by shaping malleable objects and letting them harden or by chipping away pieces from a rock (sculpting).
The drawing of air into the lungs, accomplished in mammals by elevation of the chest walls and flattening of the diaphragm, as part of the act of respiration.
Something or someone which creates or makes something.
A painting, drawing, sculpture or other piece of creative, visual art
An instance of exhibiting.
A substance that is applied as a liquid or paste, and dries into a solid coating that protects or adds color/colour to an object or surface to which it has been applied.
A rapidly executed freehand drawing that is not intended as a finished work, often consisting of a multitude of overlapping lines.
A person who sculpts; an artist who produces sculpture.
The making of architectural or design drawings.
A picture, likeness, diagram or representation, usually drawn on paper.
The act of illustrating; the act of making clear and distinct; education; also, the state of being illustrated, or of being made clear and distinct.
An image, symbol, picture, or other representation usually as an object of religious devotion.
A three dimensional work of art created by shaping malleable objects and letting them harden or by chipping away pieces from a rock (sculpting).
A room, group of rooms, or other space where works of art are placed on display, possibly for sale.
Relating to, or having the characteristics of, an icon.
A person who draws pictures (especially illustrations in books or magazines)
To fit, as for a specific end or purpose; make suitable or comfortable; adapt; adjust.
The study of art or beauty.
A person who manages, administers or organizes a collection, either independently or employed by a museum, library, archive or zoo.
A grotesque representation of a figure; a gargoyle.
Any of very many genres of art from the late 19th to the mid 20th centuries.
A source of inspiration.
The study or philosophy of beauty.
An exact skill that needs practice to perfect.
A picture of a celebrity, an event etc., intended to be attached to a wall.
The act of archiving something.
Something created such as an invention or artwork.
A painting, drawing, sculpture or other piece of creative, visual art
To shed light upon.
A piece of work that has been given much critical praise, especially one that is considered the greatest work of a person's career.
The art or practice of writing letters and words in a decorative style; the letters and words so written.
An art or craft object made by hand.
An art form intended to be appreciated or perceived primarily by sight, such as painting, photography, printmaking, and filmmaking.
An acrylic resin.
A painter who paints in this style
In an artistic manner.
A painting technique using paint made of colorants suspended or dissolved in water.
A great or important work of literature, music or art, a masterpiece.
To form by sculpture.
(sometimes derogatory) Inclined towards the arts; arty.
Pretending to artistic worth; high-flown.
An upright frame, typically on three legs, for displaying or supporting something, such as an artist's canvas.
A paint in which the colours or pigments are suspended in an oil-based carrier such as linseed oil which hardens on exposure to the air.
A thin brush for applying paint.
A work of art with some artistic merit.
Strength; power; might; force .
A person directly involved in a creative marketing process.
Drawings or words drawn on a surface in a public place, usually made without authorization.
An optical or other representation of a real object; a graphic; a picture.
The middle layer of the wall of a blood vessel or lymph vessel which is composed of connective and muscular tissue.
Strength; power; might; force .
A visual symbol or emblem that acts as a trademark or a means of identification of a company or organization.
The structural elements of a building or other constructed object.
The act of animating, or giving life or spirit.
(except in phrases) Satisfaction, contentment; pleasure.
Graphism of symbols such as letters that express some meaning.
